I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Cambodia asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical assistance to prepare a program to develop the private sector and small and medium-
sized enterprises (SMEs). The program preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) reflects ADB’s 
continuous support for private sector development (PSD) policy reform.1 Conceptualization of 
this assistance was based on lessons from the implementation of past and ongoing projects and 
consultations  with  the  Government.  The  PPTA  is  included  in  the  ADB  country  operations 
business plan for Cambodia,2 which emphasizes private sector and SME development as one of 
the key pillars of the development assistance strategy for the country. 
 
2.  The Fact-Finding Mission visited Phnom Penh, Cambodia during 12–14 November 2007. 
The  Mission  and  representatives  from  the  Government  held  discussions  and  reached  an 
understanding on the objective, scope, cost, and implementation arrangements for the PPTA. 
The PPTA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The challenge for the Government is to sustain its high economic growth of 9%–10% per 
annum, accelerate the creation of productive jobs, and continue reducing poverty. This is no 
easy task with half of the population under 20 years old and more than 80% of employment in 
the informal sector (mainly subsistence agriculture). The Government recognizes that the key to 
sustaining high economic growth and poverty reduction is to diversify sources of growth (The 
initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2). This requires more difficult reforms to 
improve competitiveness throughout the supply chain. Sustaining high economic growth over 
the longer term will require export diversification as well as building linkages between agriculture 
and the modern sector. Improving competitiveness by continuing to reduce distortions or costs 
at the border (such as tariff and nontariff policy barriers to trade, and inefficiencies in trade 
facilitation), distortions within domestic trade, and improved access to technology will be critical 
to achieving this outcome. The Government considers the private sector will be central to its 
diversification  strategy.  SMEs  are  the  dominant  business form  in  Cambodia  and  therefore 
should be treated as the private sector norm and not the exception.  
 
4.  Recent investment surveys and several value-chain studies have identified impediments 
to  Cambodia  realizing  its  medium-term  growth  potential.  Surveys  on  business  climate 
perceptions suggest that, among other factors, excessive red tape, remaining distortions in the 
trade regime, tax administration, access to finance, and corruption are some of the major 
obstacles to private sector growth and development. Value-chain studies3 identify poor product 
quality,  an  inadequate  sanitary  and  phytosanitary  standards  (SPS)  policy  framework, 
underdeveloped linkages between the rural and modern sectors of the economy, and relatively 
costly logistics as constraints to export diversification. A common thread in many of these value-
chain studies is a weak competition policy framework broadly defined to include remaining 
distortions at the border and within domestic trade (or behind the border). On 5 December 2007, 
the Government (Ministry of Commerce [MOC]) launched its Diagnostic Trade Integration Study 
(DTIS), which will provide a broad agenda for expanding the private sector by improving both 
foreign and domestic trade, and in particular developing efficient backward linkages in the

5.  SME Development. The Government sees access to finance, standards, and product 
quality as key impediments to SME development. Recent studies indicate that SMEs are more 
likely to have problems accessing basic technology (both demand and supply side) compared to 
larger firms. Interest rates charged by banks for lending to SMEs remains very high. Much has 
been done to improve the legal framework for improving SME access to finance, including the 
recently passed law on secured transactions, which establishes the legal framework for secured 
collateral on movables. The Small and Medium Enterprise Development Program (SMEDP) 
supports the Government’s efforts to draft a law on lease financing and simplifying accounting 
procedures and guidelines for SMEs.5 The Second Financial Sector Program is supporting the 
Government’s efforts to improve intermediation and efficiency in banking.6 It will operationalize 
the credit information bureau, which will improve SME access to credit in the longer term. 
Improvement in capacity to implement the law on secured transactions will help create a better 
lending environment for SMEs. Efforts are also needed to address demand-side gaps for credit, 
including improving the market for professional business services, product quality, and SPS.  
 
6.  Trade  Policy  and  Export  Diversification.  The  ability  of  Cambodian  exporters  to 
compete in commodities other than garments and tourism remains limited. Export diversification 
is  constrained  by  poor  product  quality,  unreliable  supply  especially  of  agriculture  produce, 
technical barriers to trade, inefficient logistics, and cumbersome export documentation. The 
Government has prioritized export diversification as an important source of economic growth 
and poverty reduction. The DTIS identifies 19 products as pilot studies for catalyzing a broad-
based reform agenda, while at the same time recognizing the necessity for specific reforms and 
capacity-building  initiatives  in  some  sectors.  Meanwhile,  the  Government  is  completing  its 
remaining  World  Trade  Organization  commitments  including  developing  mechanisms  for 
antidumping and safeguards. In this regard, the Government must continue to strengthen its 
processes and procedures for trade policy formulation taking an economywide approach.  
 
7.  Domestic Trade. The Government recognizes that the domestic trade services sector is 
a major generator of jobs and incomes. It also recognizes that an efficient domestic distribution 
system is critical for getting products to international markets and for developing backward 
linkages with agriculture. Improving logistics and trade facilitation are essential to successfully 
develop backward linkages. International experience demonstrates that the modern wholesale 
and  retail  sectors  (restaurants,  hotels,  supermarkets)  and  the  traditional  wet  markets  are 
important  channels  for  moving  goods  efficiently  from  the  farm  to  the  urban  consumer. 
Supermarkets are still in their infancy but experiencing rapid growth in line with Cambodia’s 
rapidly growing per capita incomes. However, supermarkets and hotels import most of their 
fresh produce. Ensuring an enabling environment for the retail sector to continue to grow and at 
the same time developing appropriate modalities for facilitating mutually commercial linkages 
between farmers and supermarkets will be critical if Cambodian farmers are to increase their 
gains from this longer-term growth. Success for farmers in the domestic market will be a 
platform for success in the international market.

8.  Investment Climate. The Government considers extending the business registry to the 
provinces and commencing a licensing review as priorities for improving the investment climate. 
The SMEDP is helping streamline registration procedures and established a national enterprise 
electronic registry housed at MOC. This reform effort has significantly reduced the time required 
to register a business and resulted in increased business registration. Two pilot provinces have 
almost completed establishment of a registry; the evaluation will provide lessons for extending 
the registry to other provinces. 
 
9.  The Government lacks a system whereby laws and regulations affecting licensing and 
inspection  are  reviewed  to  determine  the  impact  on  the  private  sector.  As  a  result,  the 
Government lacks appreciation of the regulatory compliance costs imposed on the private 
sector. The Council of Ministers approved the licensing reform agenda and guidelines to line 
ministries for carrying out a review developed under the SMEDP. Further reforms are required 
to develop or refine the appropriate mechanism for line ministries to commence the review. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the PPTA is to improve the business environment so that the private 
sector  can  operate  efficiently.  Two  outcomes  are  expected:  (i)  technical  inputs  to  the 
Government and ADB to formulate a private sector and SME development program loan that 
helps reduce poverty and increase jobs by expanding the private sector, and (ii) technical 
background  papers  on  the  Government’s  PSD  agenda  anchored  in  its  trade  development 
strategy and DTIS. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The key PPTA activities are divided into four components; each component will be 
considered a stand-alone component.  
 
12.  Component 1: SME Development. Several studies indicate that SMEs are more likely 
than larger firms to have problems accessing basic technology and finance. This component will 
develop  a  series  of  technical  papers  that  explore  ways  to  address  these  SME-specific 
constraints by (i) drawing on international best practices to assess the appropriate public policy 
approach and measures for promoting technology diffusion to SMEs, and design a practical 
policy framework for technology; (ii) examining why interest rates are high; (iii) exploring ways to 
improve the market for professional business service providers including accounting and other 
consulting services; and (iv) drawing on ADB’s trade facilitation work with the Greater Mekong 
Subregion to assess the policy and strategic framework for SPS and product quality, and 
develop the appropriate public and private policy response. 
 
13.  Component 2: Trade Policy and Export Diversification. A key development objective 
of the Government is to diversify exports through market-based reforms as articulated in the 
DTIS. Another objective is to strengthen capacity to formulate policy. This component will 
provide a series of technical background papers that identify ways an ensuing PSD program 
could assist the Government in achieving these two objectives. The PSD program is expected 
to be anchored in the Government’s trade development strategy taking a sectorwide approach. 
Activities under this component include (i) synthesize the key findings of current value-chain 
studies; identify key crosscutting policy, regulatory, and structural constraints facing producers;

4   
and propose policy recommendations for the PSD program; (ii) support MOC with analytical 
work  on  economywide  impacts  of  crosscutting  economic  reforms  (also  effective  rates  of 
protection) to assist in prioritizing reform measures for the PSD program and build in-house 
capacity to assess proposed preferential trade agreements; and (iii) identify ways the PSD 
program can assist MOC in building trade capacity such as developing the mechanism and 
human resource needs for antidumping and safeguards under its World Trade Organization 
commitments and other related agencies.  
 
14.  Component 3: Domestic Trade Sector. The consultants will work with the Government 
and stakeholders to explore ways to improve efficiency of domestic distribution as a key channel 
for  supporting  trade  facilitation  and  exports,  and  developing  backward  linkages.  Activities 
include (i) develop appropriate public and private policy options, and design a program for 
linking producers of horticulture produce (vegetables and fruits identified in the DTIS) with the 
modern retail sector; and (ii) drawing on ADB’s Greater Mekong Subregion trade facilitation 
initiatives, identify measures to improve the logistics subsector using a sectorwide approach.  
 
15.  Component 4: Investment Climate. This component comprises two activities: (i) work 
with  the  Government  to  develop  its  competition  policy  framework;  and  (ii)  building  on  the 
business climate reforms under the ongoing SMEDP, support Government efforts to establish 
business registry offices in the provinces; and develop appropriate mechanisms for developing 
a “whole of government” approach to regulatory review. The consultants will draw on findings 
from  the  upcoming  World  Bank  investment  climate  assessment  in  developing  all  four 
components.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated to be $650,000 equivalent. ADB will provide 
$550,000, financed on a grant basis by ADB’s technical assistance funding program. The 
Government’s contribution will be in-kind and cover items of expenditure estimated at $100,000 
equivalent.  Appendix  3  gives  the  details  of  cost  estimates  and  the  financing  plan.  The 
Government has been informed that approval of the PPTA does not commit ADB to finance any 
ensuing project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Ministry of Mines, Industry and Energy will be the Executing Agency for the PPTA. 
MOC  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency.  The  ADB  project  team,  in  coordination  with  the 
Cambodian  Resident  Mission,  will  coordinate  implementation  with  all  stakeholders  and 
development partners. 
 
18.  The PPTA will be implemented over 8 months from February 2008 to September 2008, 
coinciding with the processing of the PSD program at the end of 2008. A team of international 
consultants will be paired with national consultants (35 person-months total) to implement the 
PPTA  activities:  seven  international  consultants  for  11  person-months  and  six  national 
consultants for 24 person-months. The terms of reference for the consulting services are in 
Appendix  4).  ADB  will  recruit  the  consultants  individually.  Consultants  will  be  engaged  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time).  The  consultants  will  procure  the  equipment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). To facilitate advance disbursements for the 
farmer supply survey, workshops, publications, and statistical software, an advance payment

5
facility will be required. About two workshops will be held to encourage participatory discussions 
with  stakeholders  from  Government,  the  private  sector,  and  development  partners  on  the 
various technical background papers and as input to preparation of the PSD program. About 50 
participants are expected to attend each workshop. 
 
19.  The consultants will be responsible for providing reports and deliverables as required 
under their terms of references. Each component will produce a final report on activities. The 
timing of each PPTA activity will be determined in consultation with MOC. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $550,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for preparing the Private Sector and Small and Medium-Sized 
Enterprise Development Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

as the centerpiece of the strategy. Private sector expansion is a key pillar of ADB’s country strategy and program. 
Private sector expansion will lead to further poverty reduction.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  Seven international and six national consultants will be engaged for the project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA). 
 
A.   Component 1: Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise Development 
 
2.  This component will engage specialists on technology adoption and access to business 
service providers, finance, and sanitary and phytosanitary standards (SPS). 
  
1.  Business  Development  Specialist  (Technology  Adoption)  (international,  
2 person-months) 
 
3.   The consultant will conduct a technical report on backward linkages of small and medium-
sized enterprises (SMEs) and their low technology adoption rate, and report directly to the Ministry 
of Industry, Mining and Energy (MIME) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) officer responsible.   
 
4.  The consultant will be a specialist in development economics with strong expertise in 
technology adoption and business development services. The  main tasks include (i) examine 
factors for the poor backward linkages of some key economic sectors, including garments and 
agriculture; (ii) identify key barriers to SMEs adopting technology; (iii) review the policy, legal, and 
regulatory environment for technology and business professional services providers (accountants 
and  others),  including regulations on  entry/competition;  (iv)  review  the  policy  environment  for 
education institutes as providers of courses in professional business services in Cambodia; and (v) 
identify potential measures for improving SME technology adoption and access to professional 
business services providers drawing from best international practices.  
 
5.  Deliverable. Within 3 months of inception submit a final report titled SME’s Backward 
Linkages and Technology Adoption in Cambodia: Identifying the Appropriate Policy for Technology 
as agreed with MIME and ADB, and to the satisfaction of MIME and ADB. . 
 
2.  Financial Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
6.   The specialist will prepare a technical report on interest rates, and report directly to MIME 
and the ADB officer responsible. The consultant will be a specialist in financial sectors in emerging 
markets with knowledge of SME financing and in-depth knowledge of the Cambodian financial 
sector. The main tasks include (i) examine the sources of the high cost of lending to SMEs, and  
(ii) identify potential mitigation measures drawing from best international practices. 
 
7.  Deliverable. Within 6 weeks of inception, submit a final report titled The Sources of the 
High Cost of Lending to SMEs in Cambodia as agreed with MIME and ADB, and to the satisfaction 
of MIME and ADB.  
 
3.  Sanitary and Phytostandards Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
8.   The specialist will produce a technical report on product standards framework and SPS in 
Cambodia,  and  report  directly  to  MIME  and  the  ADB  officer  responsible.  The  consultant  will 
specialize in the area of standards and SPS and have extensive knowledge of the Cambodian 
environment. The  main tasks include (i) synthesize existing work on standards, quality, and SPS 
constraints  for  SMEs  in  Cambodia;  (ii)  assess  the  policy,  legal  and  regulatory,  and  strategic

12  Appendix 4 
 
framework for standards, product quality, and SPS; and (iii) develop the appropriate public and 
private policy response for improving product quality, standards, and SPS.  
 
9.  Deliverable. Within 2 months of inception, submit a final report titled The Policy and 
Strategic Framework for Improving Product Standards and SPS as agreed with MIME, Ministry of 
Commerce (MOC), and ADB, and to the satisfaction of MIME, MOC, and ADB.  
 
4.  Project Coordinator (national, 7 person-months) 
 
10.  The consultant will coordinate activities of the international and national consultants. The 
consultant should be familiar with ADB processes and hold a diploma or degree in accounting. 
Responsibilities include (i) keep financial accounts of the PPTA, and provide necessary logistics to 
the consultants including making appointments; (ii) provide translation services to the ADB project 
team  and  consultants;  (iii)  liaise  between  counterparts  and  the  ADB  task  manager;  and  
(iv) provide other support as requested by the ADB project team. 
  
5.  SME Development Specialist (national, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
11.  The  consultant  will  work  with  the  business  development  specialist  and  the  standards 
specialist,  have  broad  experience  with  international  consultants,  and  have  at  least  3  years 
experience  working  on  SME  development  issues.  Responsibilities  include  (i)  report  to  the 
international consultants and provide technical support for the SME development activities; and  
(ii)  organize  logistics  for  carrying  out  the  studies,  collect  necessary  data,  regulations,  policy 
statements;  provide  translation  services,  and  respond  to  other  requests  of  the  international 
consultants.  
 
B.  Component 2: Foreign Trade and Export Diversification 
 
12.  This component will engage specialists on private sector development (PSD) and economic 
analysis.  
 
1.  Private Sector Development Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
13.  The consultant will provide a background paper to (i) survey the key priority issues for PSD, 
and (ii) synthesize the key findings from current value-chain studies; and report directly to MOC 
and the ADB officer responsible. 
 
14.  The consultant will specialize in PSD and have extensive experience and knowledge of the 
region. The main tasks include (i) draw on the Government’s agenda as outlined its Diagnostic 
Trade Integration Study (DTIS) and other documents, identify the key priorities for PSD over the 
medium-term  including  the  reform  areas  of  foreign  and  domestic  trade,  SME  development, 
investment climate, and macroeconomy with reference to best international practice in PSD in the 
presence of a resource boom; and (ii) synthesize the key findings from current value-chain studies; 
identify  the  key  crosscutting  policy,  regulatory,  and  structural  constraints  facing  producers 
(disaggregated by gender where relevant); and propose policy recommendations including any 
legal and regulatory reforms. 
 
15.  Deliverable. Within 7 weeks of inception submit final report titled Survey of Issues in 
Private Sector Development as agreed with MOC and ADB, and to the satisfaction of MOC and 
ADB.

Appendix 4  13 
2.  Economic Analyst (national, 3 person-months) 
 
16.  The consultant will provide a background technical paper on assessing the economywide 
impacts of crosscutting economic reforms synthesizing the results of the PSD specialist and other 
scenarios under the guidance of the ADB project team. The consultant will report directly to MOC 
and the ADB officer responsible.  
 
17.  The consultant will be a specialist in economywide modeling and analysis with in-depth 
knowledge  of  Cambodia’s  national  income  accounts  and  input-output  tables.  The  main  tasks 
include  (i)  develop  a  user-friendly  tool  (economywide  model  of  the  Cambodian  economy)  to 
analyze crosscutting reforms to improve competitiveness and export diversification; (ii) identify 
crosscutting reforms by using findings from ADB’s PSD consultant and other scenarios under the 
guidance of the ADB project team and the Government counterpart; (iii) simulate scenarios of a 
resource boom effect on the nonresource private sector; (iv) estimate effective rates of protection 
drawing on the work of the competition policy specialist in component 4; and (v) develop a training 
module and provide training for officials on the economic model.  
  
18.  Deliverables. Within 3 months of inception, (i) submit a final report: An Economy-Wide 
Economic Model for Cambodian Economy; (ii) provide data to ADB and MOC in electronic form, 
coded, and in a form (excel spread sheet) that can be used for statistical analysis for further work 
by ADB and MOC; and (iii) provide one training workshop on the model and economic simulations. 
 
C.  Component 3: Domestic Trade: Linking Farmers with the Modern Retail Sector 
 
19.  This  component  will  engage  consultants  and  a  survey  team  to  (i)  review  the  policy 
environment in the distribution subsector (traditional small retailers, supermarkets, and logistics, 
and SPS); (ii) conduct a farmer-supermarket survey identifying ways of bringing farmers into the 
modern retail sector; and (iii) design a public-private partnership capacity-building program for 
bringing farmers into the modern retail sector. The component will comprise two international and 
two national consultants. 
 
1.  Agriculture  Economist  (Team  Leader)  (international,  3  person-months, 
intermittent) 
 
20.  The agriculture economist (team leader) will carry out a farmer supply chain-supermarket 
survey, and report directly to MOC and the ADB officer responsible.  
 
21.  The  consultant  will  be  a  specialist  in  agriculture  economics  and  possess  an  in-depth 
understanding of the transformation of the global retail sector and extensive knowledge of the 
impact of supermarkets on farmer supply chains in other developed and developing economies. 
The specialist will design a survey for farmers supplying supermarkets and those outside the 
supermarket supply chain. The design phase will include selection of one geographic area and 
produce listed in the DTIS (fruits and vegetables, corn, and cashew nuts), and comprise two 
phases. The first will involve a rapid reconnaissance study of the urban retail sector and farmer 
supply  chains.  This  will  involve  informant  interviews  with  major  supermarkets,  wholesalers, 
distribution centers, other retail formats, farmer groups, logistic providers, as well as relevant 
government authorities and researchers. This phase is to analyze the structure of the urban retail 
sector, and the competitiveness of supply chains and their transformation in the last decade; and 
identify key issues for the study and survey. The second phase involves working with the two 
national consultants to design a questionnaire and select the study area and samples (about 100 
farmers included in the survey). The survey sample will be stratified to ensure it is representative of

14  Appendix 4 
 
the characteristics (including gender) of the farming community in the identified location. The team 
leader will supervise survey implementation, summarize key findings, and provide guidance to the 
two national consultants responsible for carrying out the survey and processing the data and 
compiling the results. The team leader will be responsible for coordinating the writing of the final 
report, and carry out consultations with farmers and supermarkets in designing a future program. 
 
22.  Deliverables. Within 6 months of inception, submit final report titled Linking Farmers with 
the Modern Retail Sector: A Proposed Public-Private Sector Partnership as agreed with MOC and 
ADB,  and  to  the  satisfaction  of  MOC  and  ADB.  Other  deliverables  include  (i)  the  survey 
questionnaires; and (ii) survey data provided to ADB and MOC in electronic form, coded and in a 
form (excel spread sheet) that can be used for statistical analysis for further work by ADB and 
MOC. 
 
2.  Logistics Specialist (international, 1 person-month, intermittent) 
 
23.  The specialist will prepare technical reports on ways to improve logistics from the farm to 
the retail market, and report directly to MOC and the ADB officer responsible.  
 
24.  The  consultant  will  be  a  specialist  in  the  area  of  logistics  and  possess  an  in-depth 
understanding of the logistics subsector in the Greater Mekong Subregion. The specialist will 
synthesize existing reports and studies, including the value-chain studies on the logistics subsector 
in Cambodia, identify key crosscutting issues, and make policy recommendations for improving 
efficiency. Working with the team leader under the domestic trade component, the specialist will 
design the logistics component of the survey for farmers supplying supermarkets and those outside 
the supermarket supply chain. The design phase will include selection of one geographic area and 
produce listed in the DTIS (fruits and vegetables, corn, and cashew nuts) and comprise two 
phases. The first phase will involve a rapid reconnaissance study of the urban retail sector and 
farmer supply chains to describe the structure of the logistics subsector as it relates to the modern 
retail  sector.  This  will  involve  informant  interviews  with  major  supermarkets,  wholesalers, 
distribution centers, other retail formats, farmer groups, logistic providers, as well as relevant 
government authorities and researchers. The second phase will involve working with the national 
consultants to design the logistics component of the questionnaire, and supervising implementation 
of the logistics component of the survey. The consultant will summarize the key findings of the 
logistics component of the farmer supply-supermarket survey and identify measures (including any 
legal and regulatory measures) for improving the logistics subsector. The consultant will provide 
guidance to the two national consultants responsible for carrying out the survey and processing the 
data and compiling the results. 
 
25.  Deliverable. The consultant will be responsible for writing the final report on logistics titled 
Modern Retail Sector Logistics: Identifying Bottlenecks and Policy Recommendations. This report 
will be input into the final report on farmer supply chains.  
 
3.  National Consultants (two consultants for a total of 8 person-months, intermittent) 
 
26.  The two national consultants will work with the two international consultants, and have 
similar experience including research in the area of agriculture economics and logistics and proven 
track record in surveying farmers and statistical analysis. The national consultants must have at 
least 3 years experience working on these issues. They will be responsible for (i) reporting to the 
international consultants and providing technical support for the activities outlined for the team 
leader  and  logistics  specialist;  (ii)  organizing  logistics  for  carrying  out  the  survey  including 
arranging and training the survey interviewers, being responsible for implementing the survey,

Appendix 4  15 
collecting survey data, and processing and compiling results with guidance from the international 
specialists; and (iii) helping the Government organize and conduct workshops and seminars based 
on  the  findings  of  the  PPTA  to  build  awareness  and  strengthen  ownership  of any  proposed 
reforms/programs.  
 
D.  Component 4: Investment Climate. 
 
27.  This component will engage one international consultant and one national consultant to 
carry out a review of competition policy and propose ways to strengthen the framework. 
 
1.  Competition Policy Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
 
28.   The specialist will prepare a report on strengthening Cambodia’s framework for competition 
policy  reflecting  Cambodia’s  stage  of  development,  policy  environment,  and  Government 
administrative capacity. The task will cover the different dimensions of competition policy including 
trade policy reforms (at the border and within domestic trade), deregulation, state enterprises, 
competition law and enforcement agency, and institutional capacity building. The international 
consultant will report directly to MOC and the ADB officer responsible.  
 
29.  The consultant will be a specialist in competition policy including trade policy, industrial 
economics, and institutional economics in developing economies. Knowledge of the World Trade 
Organization would be an advantage. The main tasks include (i) evaluate trade policy (tariff policy) 
and identify any remaining nontariff barriers to trade; (ii) evaluate competition policy in three 
selected sectors, of which one sector will be the modern retail sector and traditional markets (as 
input into component 3), and others as identified by MOC and ADB (assessment for the retail 
sector  will  include  licensing  and  permit  system,  zoning  rules,  food  and  safety  rules,  etc.);  
(iii) provide inputs to the Government on the draft competition law and required institutional setup; 
(iv) develop a broad medium-term action plan that operationalizes the licensing review mechanism; 
(v) help MOC develop an action plan in its effort to develop an antidumping safeguard mechanism 
taking a sectorwide trade approach; (vi) help MOC develop a capacity building plan for the newly 
established  Department  of  International  Cooperation  at  MOC;  and  (vii)  assess  capacity 
development needs of MOC in trade policy analysis. 
 
30.  Deliverable. The consultant will be responsible for writing the final report: Developing a 
Competition Policy for Cambodia.  
 
2.  Industrial Economist (national, 2 person-months) 
 
31.  The consultant will work with the international competition policy specialist, and have at 
least 3 year’s experience in industrial economics and a proven track record in case studies. The 
consultant will report to the international consultant; provide technical support for the activities 
outlined  in  para.  31;  organize  logistics  for  carrying  out  the  studies,  collect  necessary  data, 
regulations, and policy statements; and provide translation services and meet other requests of the 
international consultant.
